Award.AwardTitle: Development of Efficient Models of Streamer to Leader Transition in the Earth's Atmosphere
Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant will allow research to continue on streamer-to-spark modeling, with a main goal of developing an efficient and accurate air heating model to study streamer-to-leader transition in lightning and air heating processes in transient luminous events (TLEs). New observations of events like gigantic jets and space leaders in lightning show the need for the development of streamer-to-leader transition models capable of simulating leader formation and propagation in a broader range of values of leader electrical current and ambient air pressure. The research aims of the award are to answer questions about: the scaling of streamer-to-leader transition with pressure, parameterization of channel decay time, polarity asymmetries in positive and negative leader formation and propagation, possibility of air heating in sprites, and long persistency of bead structures in sprites.

The broader impacts of the research include the education and training of a graduate student and the inclusion of undergraduate students in the research through direct funding and the association with an existing Research Experiences for Undergradutes program. Models developed during the award period would be made available to the community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Leaders are self-propagating electrical discharges capable of traveling kilometer-long distances at ground and near-ground pressure. Leaders are fundamental components of lightning discharges, enabling a cloud-to-ground lightning to form a highly conducting path that effectively short-circuits the gap between an electrified thundercloud and the ground. The initial stages of leader formation involve non-thermal filamentary plasmas called streamers. The goal of this project was to develop efficient and accurate air heating models for studies of streamer-to-leader transition in lightning and air heating processes in transient luminous events that occur above active thunderstorms at high altitudes in the Earth’s atmosphere. The project was largely motivated by the need to understand streamer-to-leader transition over a broad range of air pressures and electrical currents as applicable to lightning and transient luminous events. Recent observations indicate that one type of transient luminous events occurring in altitude range 60-90 km, referred to as sprites, may contain localized regions of air heating. Another type, referred to as gigantic jets, are lightning-like discharges emanating from thundercloud tops (at approximately 10 km altitude), propagating upward, and connecting to the lower ionosphere (approximately 90 km altitude), and the most recent observations have depicted gigantic jets exhibiting step like processes similar to conventional lightning leaders. The completed project developed new understanding of plasma dynamics and chemical kinetics involved in formation, stabilization and decay of leader channels.

 Specific scientific contributions made under this project include: (1) Development of a model of air heating by electrical discharges for a wide range of currents and ambient pressures explaining leader speeds observed in lightning and gigantic jets; (2) Description of the physical/chemical processes in the sprite core plasma leading to experimentally observed infrasonic radiation; (3) Development of a novel electrodynamic model for simulation of lightning leader tree growth providing, in particular,  a unified view on different kinds of electromagnetic field signatures observed during the initial stages of lightning  discharges; (4) Investigation of the properties of streamers in varying air density at sprite altitudes; (5) Development of a deconvolution technique that allows to reduce effects of phosphor persistence in high-speed observations of sprite streamers; (6) Explanation of previously reported photometric observations of a type of transient luminous events referred to as elve doubles; (7)  Development of a new insight on lightning initiation by demonstrating that streamers can be initiated when two precipitation particles cause an enhancement of the electric field by passing in close vicinity of each other. This project resulted in one Ph.D. dissertation. Additionally, the project results have been published in eight refereed journal papers.
